review.title: Cooperative Epistemic Multi-Agent Planning for Implicit Coordination
review.abstract: Epistemic planning can be used for decision making in multi-agent situations with distributed knowledge and capabilities. Recently, Dynamic Epistemic Logic (DEL) has been shown to provide a very natural and expressive framework for epistemic planning. We extend the DEL-based epistemic planning framework to include perspective shifts, allowing us to define new notions of sequential and conditional planning with implicit coordination. With these, it is possible to solve planning tasks with joint goals in a decentralized manner without the agents having to negotiate about and commit to a joint policy at plan time. First we define the central planning notions and sketch the implementation of a planning system built on those notions. Afterwards we provide some case studies in order to evaluate the planner empirically and to show that the concept is useful for multi-agent systems in practice.

sections.text: To present planning tasks as an example of a "housing loan" in the introduction, we need a formal framework in which: (1) agents can think about the knowledge and ignorance of other agents; (2) both fully and partially observable actions can be described in a compact way (Bob does not see Anne putting the key under the mat). Dynamic Epistemic Logic (DEL) fulfills these conditions. First, we briefly recapitulate the foundations of DEL according to the Conventions of Bolander and Andersen [8]. sections.heading: 3 Cooperative Planning
sections.text: As mentioned in the introduction, in this paper we assume that each measure can be carried out by a single actor, that is, that we are not considering joint measures. In our example of the "housing loan" there are two actors, Anne and Bob. They are to carry out different parts of the plan in order to achieve the goal of giving Bob access to the apartment. For example, Anne is the one who puts the key under the mat, and Bob is the one who takes it off the mat. In order to represent who executes which measures of a plan, we will introduce what we call an owner function (inspired by the approach of Lo Lions, Pacuit and Witzel [22]). An owner function is defined as a sequence: A → A, which assigns each measure to the actor who can carry it out.

sections.heading: 4.1 Russian Card Problem
sections.text: In the Russian card problem, seven cards numbered 0,.., 6 are randomly distributed to three agents. Alice and Bob get three cards each, while Eve gets the only remaining card. Initially, each agent only knows his own cards. The task now is for Alice and Bob to inform each other about their respective cards, using only public announcements, without revealing the holder of a single card to Eve. sections.heading: 5 Conclusion and Future Work
sections.text: We have introduced an interesting new cooperative, decentralized planning concept, without the need for explicit coordination or negotiation. Instead, some problems can be elegantly solved by modelling all kinds of communications directly as plannable actions and relying on the ability of autonomous actors to blame each other (by shifting perspectives) by achieving implicit coordination between actors. We have briefly shown that both sequential and conditional solution algorithms and their performance need to be formalized on the Russian card problem and two-letter transgression problems. Based on this paper, a number of challenging problems need to be addressed. First, concrete problems (e.g. epistemic versions of established multiactive planning tasks) need to be formalized, with special attention to what types of communicative actions actors need to solve these problems in an implicitly coordinated way.
